docs.snippet: LONDON, May 7--V-E Day may be tomorrow, but London could not wait. It celebrated tonight. Londoners, more entitled to cheer than most, danced and pranced in the streets and shot off flares and built great bonfires in the gaping cellars of bombed-o...
docs.lead_paragraph: LONDON, May 7--V-E Day may be tomorrow, but London could not wait. It celebrated tonight. Londoners, more entitled to cheer than most, danced and pranced in the streets and shot off flares and built great bonfires in the gaping cellars of bombed-out buildings.

headline.main: LONDONERS DANCE IN PACKED STREETS; Unable to Wait, They Light Up Bonfires and Serenade King in Joyful Celebration

byline.original: By DANA ADAMS SCHMIDT By Wireless to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.lead_paragraph: Every March through May, mango frenzy is in full swing in India, not least in Mumbai, where street vendors, fashionable bars and five-star hotels all offer mangoes in various incarnations.

docs.snippet: The people of Kyrenia, with its perfect horseshoe harbor, know something about invaders. The list reads like a Who's Who of Eastern Mediterranean history. Greeks, Romans, Saracens, Byzantines, Crusaders, Venetians and Ottomans have all held this s...
docs.lead_paragraph: The people of Kyrenia, with its perfect horseshoe harbor, know something about invaders. The list reads like a Who's Who of Eastern Mediterranean history. Greeks, Romans, Saracens, Byzantines, Crusaders, Venetians and Ottomans have all held this strategic and pretty spot. The last was the army of Turkey, which landed 29 years ago and never left. But no one here had expected the latest fleet, composed not of galleons or helicopters, but motorbikes and cars zooming down from the mountains behind the town.
docs.abstract: Greek Cypriots rush to visit Kyrenia after Turkish Cypriots ease travel across buffer zone that had divided island since 1974; many come to celebrate in little port, eating, drinking and shopping; Turks are joining them as though there never was war that tore them apart; photo; map (M)

headline.main: Kyrenia Journal; Beware These Greeks? No, They're Bearing Cash

docs.lead_paragraph: GENEVA -- The Winter Olympic Games to be held at St. Moritz from Jan. 30 to Feb. 8 are expected to bring many visitors who will remain after the Games to visit Switzerland's other winter resorts and to travel in this country whose life appears practically untouched by the effects of World War II.
docs.abstract: winter attractions; tourist officials make special bid for Amers

headline.main: WINTER IN SWITZERLAND; Tourist Officials Are Making a Special Effort to Attract American Visitors

docs.snippet: THE first thing the traveler should know about the expansion of the European Union, which happened officially yesterday, is that, contrary to a widespread expectation, not much will actually change, at least in the short term.     True, 10 countri...
docs.lead_paragraph: THE first thing the traveler should know about the expansion of the European Union, which happened officially yesterday, is that, contrary to a widespread expectation, not much will actually change, at least in the short term. True, 10 countries, 8 of them from the former East Bloc, are becoming members of the Union, and that certainly is a major historic event, signaling the disappearance of the old, almost insurmountable barrier between East and West. But it does not mean that going from, say, Germany to Poland will be like going from Germany to France, where there are no border formalities, no passports to show, no customs declarations to fill out. The tourist boards of the new member states do promise that procedures will be streamlined -- and the customs forms will be eliminated -- but the borders will not vanish, and you'll know it.
docs.abstract: Richard Bernstein travel article on what has changed and what is expected to stay same now that ten countries, eight of them from East Bloc, have joined European Union; photo (M)

docs.snippet: Calgary, Canada's energy and beef capital, is one of the country's fastest-growing cities -- with traffic congestion to match. But the benefits of surging oil and gas prices have been diluted by a slump in the cattle industry since the United Stat...
docs.lead_paragraph: Calgary, Canada's energy and beef capital, is one of the country's fastest-growing cities -- with traffic congestion to match. But the benefits of surging oil and gas prices have been diluted by a slump in the cattle industry since the United States and other countries banned the import of Canadian beef in May after the discovery of a case of mad cow disease on a ranch in northern Alberta. An economic development commission, set up late last year, is looking for ways to diversify Calgary's economy by attracting more investment in areas like health care, tourism and filmmaking. AIRPORT Several carriers from the United States, most recently Alaska Airlines, serve Calgary International Airport, 11 miles north of downtown.
docs.abstract: Profile of Calgary, Canada's energy and beef capital and one of its fastest-growing cities, as business travel destination; comments on hotels, restaurants, entertainment and business lore; photo (M)

headline.main: BUSINESS TRAVEL: ON THE GROUND -- In Calgary; A Bit of the Wild West (but Farther North) and a Skyline to Boot

docs.abstract: HR debate; Reprs Celler, Hays comment; Sen subcom approves bill to bar pub of confidential data

headline.main: Congress Weighs Passport Bills; House Supports a Moderate Plan; But Subcommittee in Senate Approves an Omnibus Security Measure That Has Stricter Travel Controls

byline.original: Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON -- The Federal Government has taken a sudden interest in making sure that tourists know what baggage is and what it is not. This interest stems from the fact that the Government exercises wide control over all exports from the United St...
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- The Federal Government has taken a sudden interest in making sure that tourists know what baggage is and what it is not. This interest stems from the fact that the Government exercises wide control over all exports from the United States, and personal baggage carried by or shipped with tourists constitutes an export.
docs.abstract: Govt tightens check on outgoing baggage to bar shipment of small items of high strategic value; redefines personal baggage and exports

headline.main: BAGGAGE CHECK TIGHTENED; Distinction Redefined Between Possessions And Exports
